# Creating Test CBZ Files
## Quick Guide
To create a test CBZ file:
1. Create a folder with your comic images (JPG, PNG, etc.) 2. Optionally create an `index.json` file with metadata 3. Select all files and compress them into a ZIP file 4. Rename the `.zip` extension to `.cbz`
## Example Structure
``` my-comic/ ├── index.json ├── 001.jpg ├── 002.jpg ├── 003.jpg └── 004.jpg ```
## Sample index.json
```json { "title": "My Awesome Comic", "author": "John Doe", "publisher": "Comic Press", "cover": "001.jpg", "year": "2024", "issue": "1", "series": "Adventures" } ```
## Supported Metadata Fields
Currently supported in the PDF: - `title` - Used as the PDF title (defaults to filename if not provided) - `author` - Set as PDF author metadata - `publisher` - Set as PDF subject metadata - `cover` - Specifies which image to use as cover (optional)
## Image Naming
Images should be named in a way that sorts naturally: - ✅ Good: `001.jpg`, `002.jpg`, `003.jpg` - ✅ Good: `page-001.jpg`, `page-002.jpg` - ❌ Bad: `1.jpg`, `2.jpg`, `10.jpg` (10 would come before 2)
## Creating CBZ on Different Platforms
### macOS 1. Select all files in Finder 2. Right-click → Compress 3. Rename `Archive.zip` to `comic.cbz`
### Windows 1. Select all files 2. Right-click → Send to → Compressed (zipped) folder 3. Rename `.zip` to `.cbz`
### Linux ```bash zip -r comic.cbz index.json *.jpg ```
